frameDefinitions: This frame describes intentionally formed human social groups (here termed Organizations) with some definite structure and Members.
Two or more distinct entities, which may be concrete or abstract objects or types, are characterized as being similar to each other.
The Support, a phenomenon or fact,  lends support to a claim or proposed course of action, the Proposition, where the Domain_of_relevance may also be expressed.
A particular piece of Information is evaluated for its accuracy.
A Communicator conveys a Message to an Addressee; the Topic and Medium of the communication also may be expressed.
A Phenomenon is portrayed with respect to the Degree of likelihood that it will  be perceived and known, given the (usually implicit)
frameExamples:
A mulberry is very <t>similar</t> in shape
to a loganberry
The latest poll results <t>show</t> that support of the president is at an all-time low.
Is your reputation at risk due to <t>incorrect</t> information?
Let's hope it did n't have time to <t>communicate</t> any of its findings to its overlords.
It's abundantly <t>obvious</t> that we'll need to spend more time on public perception.
listRoleDefinitions: The entity of which the individuals are <fen>Members</fen>.
A person belonging to an <fen>Organization</fen>.
This role describes the general location where the <fen>Organization</fen> operates, but does not indicate the possessor of the <fen>Organization</fen>.
This role marks constituents that express the set of objects or types whose similarity is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the entity characterized by its similarity to <fen>Entity_2</fen>, whose characteristics are assumed to be known.  <fen>Entity_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Entities</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Entity_2</fen> is the one whose characteristics are assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing characteristics of <fen>Entity_1</fen>.
This role marks constituents which express a property in respect to which the similarity of the entities is assessed.
A fact about <fen>Entity_1</fen> or the <fen>Entities</fen> that reveals how <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the same or different from other entities.  (Note the contrast with 'as to'.)
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the similarity occurs or exists.
The Place is the general area in which similarity occurs or exists
Support is a fact that lends epistemic support to a claim, or that provides a reason for a course of action. Typically it is expressed as an External Argument.
This is a belief, claim, or proposed course of action to which the Support lends validity. Normally it is expressed as a Finite Clause Complement:
The <fen>Information</fen> matches or does not match the facts of the world.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the agent who holds the correct/incorrect information.
The event which communicates the <fen>Information</fen>.
The Topic about which the Source has accurate information.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Information</fen> or the <fen>Source</fen> is correct.
The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
The location where the act of communication occurs.
The entity or facts that are undeniable given the <fen>Evidence</fen>.
The gradable aspect of a <fen>Phenomenon</fen> which concerns how likely it is that the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> be known. This frame element is incorporated by the lexical units in this frame.
A modifier expressing  the deviation of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> from the norm or from the value for another <fen>Phenomenon</fen> in terms of how likely the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> would be known.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is obvious
listRoleExamples: <fex>The two painters</fex> were alike in being unable to draw acceptably .
In the first phase <fex>Barthes's approach</fex> has similarities to that of Levi-Strauss.
The results of Method 2 show remarkable similarity <fex>to those obtained by Method 1</fex>
The disc announced Friday is <fex>physically</fex> similar to current music CDs
His presidency was different <fex>in that it offered a way forward for the common man</fex> .
<fex>The fact that you lied to me</fex> shows that I shouldn't trust you.
The fact that you lied to me shows <fex>that I shouldn't trust you</fex>.
<fex>He</fex> finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents .
How do you communicate to them <fex>that you really like them</fex> ?
Had someone communicated to the capital <fex>about the flagrant disregard of the religious law</fex> ?
Opinions are usually communicated <fex>over the telephone</fex> and are often given within 24 hours.
It is obvious for example <fex>that 9/10 is not the same as 1</fex>.
It is <fex>abundantly</fex> obvious you have not a clue how the Retro Program works.
It is obvious <fex>now</fex> that Senator O. T. Tawa has no plan.
